entity1.name: Hoaxes
entity1.description: Deceptive acts or practices intended to mislead or trick people, often for amusement, profit, or other purposes.;;;Deceptive acts or fabrications that are often spread to mislead people.;;;Deceptive practices in the art world where fake artworks are created and presented as authentic pieces by famous artists.;;;False or misleading information that is spread, regardless of intent to mislead.;;;Deceptive or false information presented as if it were real, often used to entertain or manipulate.
entity1.chunkid: Famous Hoaxes in History1;;;Famous Hoaxes in History22;;;Famous Hoaxes in History24;;;Famous Hoaxes in History15

entity2.name: Human History
entity2.description: The entire span of recorded events and developments that have occurred throughout the existence of human civilization.

entity3.name: Piltdown Man
entity3.description: A famous archaeological hoax in which a human skull and an orangutan's jawbone were combined to create what was claimed to be the 'missing link' between humans and apes.;;;A purported fossilized hominid skull that was claimed to be an important discovery in the study of human evolution but later found to be a hoax.;;;A fraudulent paleoanthropological find, claimed to be the missing link between humans and apes, discovered in England in 1912.;;;A famous scientific fraud where a human skull and an orangutan's jawbone were presented as the remains of an early human ancestor, misleading the scientific community for decades.
entity3.chunkid: Famous Hoaxes in History4;;;Famous Hoaxes in History7;;;Famous Hoaxes in History23;;;Famous Hoaxes in History5

entity4.name: England
entity4.description: A country that is part of the United Kingdom, located on the island of Great Britain.

entity6.name: hominid
entity6.description: A member of the family Hominidae, which includes humans and their closest evolutionary ancestors.

entity7.description: The year when the forgery was revealed.

entity8.name: human cranium
entity8.description: A part of the human skull, specifically the section that encloses and protects the brain.

entity9.name: orangutan jawbone
entity9.description: The lower jaw of an orangutan, a great ape species native to Asia.

entity11.name: scientific community
entity11.description: A collective term referring to scientists and researchers who contribute to and advance knowledge in various fields of science.

entity12.name: evolutionary theory
entity12.description: The scientific explanation for the diversity of life on Earth, proposing that species change over time through natural selection and other mechanisms.

entity13.name: Cardiff Giant
entity13.description: A 10-foot-tall petrified man that was part of a hoax discovered in Cardiff, New York.;;;A famous hoax in the form of a large stone sculpture, created to appear as an ancient petrified giant.;;;A famous hoax in the form of a large stone sculpture resembling a petrified man, created and exhibited in Cardiff, New York.
entity13.chunkid: Famous Hoaxes in History10;;;Famous Hoaxes in History8;;;Famous Hoaxes in History9

entity14.name: Cardiff
entity14.description: A town in New York where the Cardiff Giant hoax took place.

entity15.name: New York
entity15.description: The state in which the town of Cardiff is located, and where the Cardiff Giant was discovered.

entity16.description: The year when the Cardiff Giant hoax was carried out.

entity18.name: George Hull
entity18.description: The creator of the Cardiff Giant hoax, who sought to profit from public interest in archaeology and myths about giants.

entity20.name: War of the Worlds
entity20.description: A 1938 radio drama directed by Orson Welles, which caused widespread panic as many listeners believed it to be a real news report about an alien invasion.;;;A radio broadcast that caused mass hysteria in 1938, presented as a realistic news bulletin.;;;A famous radio drama that caused widespread panic by presenting a fictional alien invasion as real news.
entity20.chunkid: Famous Hoaxes in History14;;;Famous Hoaxes in History23;;;Famous Hoaxes in History11

entity21.name: Orson Welles
entity21.description: An American actor, director, writer, and producer who directed the War of the Worlds radio broadcast.

entity22.description: The year in which Orson Welles' War of the Worlds radio broadcast took place.

entity23.name: H.G. Wells
entity23.description: A British writer, best known for his work in the science fiction genre.

entity24.name: Martian invasion
entity24.description: A fictional event where beings from Mars invade Earth, often used as a plot device in science fiction.

entity26.name: mass media
entity26.description: The means of communication used to disseminate information or entertainment to the general public, including television, radio, newspapers, and the internet.

entity27.name: Han van Meegeren
entity27.description: A Dutch painter and art forger, known for his ability to create convincing forgeries of old master paintings.;;;A Dutch painter and forger who became infamous for creating and selling fake Vermeer paintings during the 1930s and 1940s.;;;A Dutch forger of paintings, known for his elaborate art hoaxes in the early 20th century.
entity27.chunkid: Famous Hoaxes in History16;;;Famous Hoaxes in History18;;;Famous Hoaxes in History15

entity30.name: Vermeer
entity30.description: Johannes Vermeer, a Dutch Baroque Period painter who specialized in domestic interior scenes of middle-class life.;;;A Dutch painter known for his works during the Baroque period.
entity30.chunkid: Famous Hoaxes in History16;;;Famous Hoaxes in History17

entity32.name: Hermann GÃ¶ring
entity32.description: A prominent and high-ranking Nazi leader in Germany during World War II.

entity34.name: art experts
entity34.description: Professionals or scholars who specialize in the study, evaluation, and authentication of artworks.

entity35.name: Sokal Affair
entity35.description: A hoax conducted in 1996 by physicist Alan Sokal to critique postmodernist academic discourse.;;;A 1996 academic publishing hoax in which physicist Alan Sokal submitted a deliberately nonsensical paper to the cultural studies journal Social Text, sparking debate about the credibility of postmodernist scholarship.
entity35.chunkid: Famous Hoaxes in History19;;;Famous Hoaxes in History21

entity36.description: The year in which the Sokal Affair took place, highlighting issues within certain academic circles.

entity37.name: postmodernist academic discourse
entity37.description: A form of scholarly communication and writing that emerged from postmodern philosophy, often characterized by its critique of traditional scientific methods and emphasis on cultural relativism.

entity38.name: Alan Sokal
entity38.description: A physicist who submitted a fake paper to test the rigor of academic journals.

entity39.name: Transgressing the Boundaries: Towards a Transformative Hermeneutics of Quantum Gravity
entity39.description: The title of a fake paper submitted by Alan Sokal to the journal Social Text.

entity40.name: Social Text
entity40.description: An academic journal that published Alan Sokal's nonsensical paper without recognizing its lack of scientific rigor.

entity42.name: postmodernist
entity42.description: A broad and often controversial movement in philosophy, art, and culture that emerged in the late 20th century, characterized by skepticism towards grand narratives, emphasis on cultural relativism, and deconstruction of traditional concepts.

entity44.name: historical narratives
entity44.description: Accounts of past events, people, and places that form a part of history, often shaped by cultural perspectives and biases.

entity45.name: established beliefs
entity45.description: Widely accepted ideas or principles within a society or community that are considered to be true or valid.

entity49.name: manipulation
entity49.description: The action of influencing someone in a clever and unscrupulous way, often for personal gain.

entity50.name: critical thinking
entity50.description: The ability to think clearly and rationally, understanding the logical connection between ideas.
